title: Why does anything exist when there should be nothing? - Quora

response.answer_text: Because the Higgs field allowed subatomic particles to have mass. That’s the simple explanation and everything follows from that. The attraction of the subatomic particles to form the first atoms, the attraction of those atoms, the “primordial hydrogen”, the formation of the first stars, the formation of the more complex elements within those stars, etc, etc. All pretty well understood. Now… to go back in time before the “Big Bang” that released that vast amount of pure energy …. We are on shaky ground. There are a number of hypotheses. The “why” of all this assumes two entirely different questions. To a physicist, the “why” would be… “what are the processes that caused the initial phases of the universe to come into being.” The physicist would not be looking for “purpose”, only explanation. To someone of a philosophical, metaphysical, or religious bent…. Then the “why?” Would assume purpose, plan, or design. You may plumb the depths of those disciplines if you wish, and perhaps find something you find resonant. But to me, I’ll simply quote Monsiuer La Place…. “I have no need of that hypothesis.”

What led you to the conclusion that there should be nothing? People often ask how the universe came into existence or how something can come from nothing. I think these questions are inherently flawed as they assume the following: 1. The universe had a beginning 2. That “nothingness” exists First of all, some models suggest the universe may have never had a “beginning”. Yes, the Big Bang happened; however, the Big Bang says nothing about a  or a “beginning”. The Big Bang is simply a model of the very dense, hot state of the early universe as it was undergoing expansion starting from  (extrapolating further back would require a theory of quantum gravity). Secondly, I don’t think there’s such thing as nothingness. Even true vacuums contain spacetime. A true state of nothingness would be the absence of spacetime. That might not even be possible. When we try to picture nothingness, we often picture a black void...But that’s still something! I think the notion of nothingness is simply a meaningless construct that might have originated from humans attempting to contemplate the cessation of consciousness. You could argue that an empty set { } contains nothing; however, that’s mathematics, and mathematics doesn’t always translate to reality. So it’s possible that there is no such thing as nothingness. Of course, I could be wrong.
